author: gisella-quintana
title: Cómo recrear la estética ‘old money’ con prendas accesibles | Moda | La Revista | El Universo
text: Desde hace un par de años en redes sociales se ha visto el resurgimiento de una estética que nació durante las décadas de los 80 y 90 proveniente de familias adineradas por generaciones. Se reconoce fácilmente por los patrones clásicos, colores neutros (beige, blanco, negro, azul marino y pasteles), combinaciones monocromáticas, materiales de alta calidad y que no tiene afán por mostrar logos ni marcas. Este estilo se ha bautizado como old money. Una de las grandes referentes de esta moda es la fallecida princesa Diana de Gales, aunque las madrinas más actuales del old money son Kate Middleton, la nueva princesa de Gales; Sofia Richie, hija menor del cantante Lionel Richie; Victoria Beckham; y Jasmine Tookes, modelo de Victoria’s Secret que solo viste en tonos sobrios. [‘Coquette’, ‘aesthetic’, ‘old money’, ‘mob wife’... ¿De qué se tratan todas las tendencias de moda que vemos en redes sociales?](https://www.eluniverso.com/larevista/moda/coquette-aesthetic-old-money-mob-wife-de-que-se-tratan-todas-las-tendencias-de-moda-que-vemos-en-redes-sociales-nota/) A simple vista parece un estilo difícil de llevar, por todo lo que implicaría tener un armario igualito al de ellas. Publicidad Pero para los admiradores de esta estética hay una opción accesible. La tienda departamental Eta Fashion acaba de lanzar una línea inspirada en estos looks que nunca pasan de moda, con prendas que cuestan desde los $19.99, asegura Vivi Fernández, ejecutiva de marketing de Eta Fashion. “Como la moda es cíclica, vuelven las faldas con tablones, los colores como los nudes, los blancos, los rosa pastel, azul marino con detalles bastante significativos que realzan este estas prendas para tener sofisticación tanto en mujeres como hombres”, explica la vocera. “El old money regresa reinventándose e innovando con otros aplicativos que le dan un factor diferenciador, pero que se mantiene como la estética de los años 80-90, con nuevas telas, nuevas texturas y también otras combinaciones que pueden adaptarse a los outfits”. [Blogueras de moda ecuatorianas reviven los estilos del 2022 y predicen tendencias](https://www.eluniverso.com/larevista/moda/blogueras-de-moda-local-reviven-estilos-del-2022-y-predicen-tendencias-para-el-2023-nota/) La idea es elegante, cómodos y sofisticados, con el resto de las piezas de la colección: pantalones holgados, camisas, camisetas blancas, detalles con botones dorados, chaquetas abiertas, y accesorios como pañoletas. Publicidad “Queremos dar a conocer también que son prendas con telas exclusivas, más estructuradas, más elaboradas, con texturas suaves. No necesariamente ostentosas, pero a su vez delicadas. Existe una combinación de tejidos para prendas superiores como inferiores que posibilita outfits que no son costosos... Pueden hacer atuendos variados con muy pocas prendas, ya que son básicas, que se ven estéticas y se adaptan para cualquier tipo de personalidad”, puntualiza Fernández. (E)

author: gloslivenews@reachplc.com (Phil Norris)
title: Post-Christmas crime spree sees presents stolen from church and cars
text:
While most of us exchanged gifts and showed kindness to fellow human beings, others went out to steal stuff from others. A series of post-Christmas
crimes saw people take presents meant for other people.
Even a church was not off-limits as a church in
Gloucester was targeted by thieves who made off with presents, an electric keyboard and a mixing deck. While presents were also stolen from a car in Cheltenham.
Gloucestershire police have issued a number of
Community Alerts about the crimes in the hope of spreading warnings about not leaving valuables in cars. There is also the hope that people may have information to help catch those responsible for ruining Christmas for the victims.
READ MORE:
Met Office gives its verdict on 15-day 'snow bomb' set to hit UK
READ MORE:
Massive scorpion found in Cotswolds village
Below, you can see some of the crimes listed by police. If you wish to update police on an incident or tell them about an existing case visit
here, to report a crime visit here.
List of crimes
A vehicle has been entered by unknown means, an untidy search has taken place and bags of presents left in the boot have been stolen including, a blue Trespass backpack, tortilla press, a jumper, toy cars and items of clothing. The incident happened in White Cross Square, Cheltenham between 12pm and 5pm on Tuesday, December 26. Incident 250 of 26/12/2023.
Two suspects have used what is possibly a crowbar to force open a church door to gain access, they have then kicked open an office door. Offenders have stolen items including an electric keyboard, a mixing desk and some Christmas presents. The incident happened in Stroud Road, Gloucester, at 6.30am on Sunday, December 24. Incident 087 of 26/12/2023.
The back passenger window of a vehicle has been smashed and items including roughly £30 cash, two Nike jackets and some Apple AirPods have been stolen. Incident in India Road, Gloucester, between 12.30am on Monday, December 25 and 10am on Tuesday, December 26. Incident 082 on 26/12/2023.
An unknown male has entered an unlocked vehicle and stolen a wallet containing approximately £00 cash and bank cards. Incident in Spring Lane, Stroud, at 4.44am on 26/12/2023. Incident 095 of 26/12/2023.
A male wearing a black Under Armour coat, blue and red hoodie and white trainers can be seen on CCTV using a crowbar to break into an outbuilding. The offender removed the door and stole an amount of alcohol stored in the building. The offender was on a pushbike and had a dog with him. Incident in Vale Road, Bishop's Cleeve, between 8.30pm on Sunday, December 24 and 9am on Wednesday, December 27). Incident 093 of 27/12/2023.
Unknown offenders have gained access to a business premises by climbing through a rear window. Till drawer and housing have been stolen and an unknown amount of cash. Incident in Rotunda Terrace, Cheltenham, at around 9.03pm on Tuesday, December 26. Incident 301 of 26/12/2023.
Offenders have gained access to a property by unknown means, possibly picking a lock as no sign of forced entry. Offenders have turned lights on and searched the property. Three high-value watches and an amount of jewellery have been stolen. Incident in Imperial Square, Cheltenham, on Tuesday, December 26. Incident 074 of 26/12/2023.
Offenders have smashed the passenger window of a vehicle parked on the road. Presents left on the rear seat have been stolen, items including a jewellery box, Puma trainers, white gold earrings and bath products. Incident in Crescent Place, Cheltenham, between 6.30pm on Tuesday, December 26 and 7.30am on Wednesday, December 27. Incident 062 of 27/12/2023.
Want our best stories with fewer ads and alerts when the biggest news stories drop? Download our app on
iPhone or Android and comment on this story.

author: Marie Claire
title: Hate to Break It to You-Tariffs Will Make Your Beauty Routine a Lot Pricier
text:
Cosmetic treatments are deeply entwined with international trade, meaning consumers should expect price hikes. If Trump’s proposed tariffs are giving you worry lines, buckle up: how you treat them might be hit next. Everything from Botox to the syringes that deliver it are facing potential price …
The White House's sweeping new tariffs have shaken global markets and left retailers scrambling. Independent brands stand to lose the most. Sali Christeson, founder and CEO of the women's workwear brand Argent, wasn't tuned in when President Trump unveiled his "Liberation Day" tariffs last …
Prepare for higher prices. Ever since President Donald Trump was declared the winner of the 2024 election, the internet has been a little less concerned with contrast makeup theory and a little more fixated on recession indicators in fashion. Specifically, the universal tariffs on imported goods …
The controversial conservative agenda received plenty of airtime during election season. But what would happen if it came to pass? Throughout this election season, Project 2025 was referenced over and over by Democrats and Republicans alike. During the presidential debate in September, Kamala Harris …

author: tecnavia
title: Spotlight on the Arts: The Closet Potter
text:
When Joan Gibson-Bevier first sat down at a pottery wheel in 1976, she knew she had found her passion. Forty- nine years later, she runs her own business, The Closet Potter, from her house in Ouray.
Seven days a week, Gibson-Bevier wakes up, walks into her studio, turns some music on for motivation, and starts making her pottery. She can easily spend three days decorating one of her pieces, but she finds this time-consuming process enjoyable. “It’s a labor of love,” she said.
While most of Bevier’s pieces are functional, she does not sacrifice style for function. Her wide variety of designs include colorful mountains, black and white abstract, aspen trees, little flowers and more. All of her pieces, however, have one thing in common: the mountain scene she always carves at the bottom.
“It’s kind of like a little surprise when you turn it over,” she said.
Not every piece turns out perfect, though.
“I have had some happy accidents, and you know, we all flop a pot now and then,” she laughed, “I’m very good at knocking things off my table after I’ve spent three days on them.”
Gibson-Bevier’s pottery has been in four galleries in Ouray over the years, but gallery shows have become difficult for her because she is almost 75 years old and has to drag the pieces back and forth, she said. That doesn’t stop her from displaying her pottery at shows, however. She likes indoor shows, and also enjoys setting up shows in her front yard.
“I just love doing shows, because I love meeting people,” she said.
Gibson-Bevier cannot work full time because of her back pain. She has 24 screws in her back from surgeries correcting her scoliosis. She does pottery on a part-time basis, working as long as she can every day before her back starts hurting.
“Here’s the beautiful part: I’m so into it that when I’m doing it, I don’t feel my pain that much,” she said. “I’m so focused on the pottery that I don’t notice the pain until I stop for lunch.”
She was born in Brooklyn, grew up in Miami, lived in Albuquerque for 24 years, lived in North Carolina for three and a half years, and moved to Ouray in a motor home by herself.
“That was the greatest adventure,” she said of moving to Ouray. “I kept waiting to get back into a relationship to do that, and then one day it dawned on me: ‘You know what? This is stupid; I can do this on my own!’” As soon as she drove down Main Street, she knew Ouray would be her home.
The business aspect of The Closet Potter comes as naturally to her as shaping the clay on the wheel. Before her pottery business, Gibson-Bevier had a career in sales. Her marketing experience and love for interacting with her customers translated perfectly when she started The Closet Potter.
Her pottery business started in a little closet in her house, and her husband, Ray, came up with her business name.
“He’s my sidekick,” she said.
Though her business has expanded to a larger room in the house, her pottery supplies still line the shelves in the tiny closet where it all started back in 2013.
Her pottery plays a large role in her daily life, scattered across her home by the Uncompahgre River. Ray cooks eggs in a dish she made, and eats them out of another. Their cabinets are stocked with colorful mugs, and there’s even a decoration outside their home that hints at the creativity inside.
In the front yard, a totem pole made of pottery stands more than four feet tall.
The colorful pole helps people find her home, and adds some personality to the yard.
Gibson-Bevier feels immensely fortunate to have turned her passion into a job, and hopes to keep the creativity flowing for as long as she can. After all, “I got a lotta livin’ to do,” she said. “I mean, I want to live till I’m 100! I have a lot to do!”
For more information visit theclosetpotter. com.
topics: Arts, Culture and Entertainment->arts and entertainment

author: Alex Co
title: These Are The Last of Us Part 2 Remastered PC Launch Times For When You'll Be Able To Start Playing
text:
Summary
- The Last of Us Part 2 Remastered will launch on PC on April 3 with simultaneous global start times.
- Naughty Dog chose to develop Intergalactic: The Heretic Prophet over The Last of Us Online.
- PC and console versions will both receive updates, with the game also coming to Steam Deck.
PC players will soon be able to experience what many consider to be Naughty Dog's finest work to date, as The Last of Us Part 2 Remastered will be available on Steam and on the Epic Games Store starting tomorrow, April 3.
While pre-load of the game is live now, for those who are looking to play the game the moment it unlocks, we're here to help with our handy The Last of Us Part 2 release times list.
Related
 Former PlayStation Boss Shuhei Yoshida Played The Last of Us Online And Thought It "Was Great"
Naughty Dog opted to develop Intergalactic: The Heretic Prophet instead of The Last of Us Online.
Here's The Exact Time When You'll Be Able To Play The Last of Us Part 2 Remastered on PC
Here's a list of the times for when the game will be playable:
- Los Angeles: April 3, 2025, at 10 AM PT
- New York: April 3, 2025, at 1 PM ET
- London: April 3, 2025, at 6 PM BST
- Rio de Janeiro: April 3, 2025, at 2 PM Brasilia Time
- Berlin: April 3, 2025, at 7 PM CEST
- Sydney: April 4, 2025, at 4 AM AEDT
- Tokyo: April 4, 2025, at 2 AM JST
- Auckland: April 4, 2025, at 6 AM NZDT
These times all line up for one simultaneous start time, which isn't the case with how digital games launch on consoles. For better or worse, everyone will be starting The Last of Us Part 2 Remastered simultaneously on PC.
Without diving into spoilers,The Last of Us Part 2 Remastered's story is one of its best-selling points, so if you haven't played the first game, it's probably better to start with that before diving into this one.
Related
 Sony Backs Down On PSN Requirement For The Last Of Us 2, Spider-Man 2 And More
Is this it, or are more games getting the same treatment?
Aside from dropping the PlayStation Network requirement in order to play the game on PC, Sony is also adding a few extras to the PC launch of TLOU2 Remastered on PC. Thankfully, console owners won't be left out, as they're also getting a game update tomorrow to add in new trophies and more.
If you're wondering if the game is worth the purchase price, read our review where we state, "In a lot of ways, The Last of Us Part II will make you angry, it will upset you, and it will break your heart as much as its glimpses of warmth and humanity will lift your spirits." The game is also Steam Deck verified, so if you plan on playing it on your portable device, it should work without a hitch.
Aside from the game's launch and a new patch for console owners, Season 2 of HBO's The Last of Us TV show is premiering this month. While we don't know how many seasons the show will run, the showrunners assure people that they won't go the Game of Thrones route, which is comforting to hear.
Related
 Neil Druckmann Reveals Zombie Horror Icon "Hated" The Last Of Us When He First Pitched It In School
In a recent discussion, Neil Druckmann, the creator of The Last Of Us, described the project's rocky start and its success at Naughty Dog.
